column3: Data and AI are two different things. Data can be turned into knowledge and that is overwhelmingly positive. There are extremely negative possibilities with AI - military use is terrifying - but I'm positive overall, as there are so many potential benefits, in healthcare, education, work in dangerous environments... loads.
column11:
Your questions about ML (machine learning) are interesting - the "extreme opinions" and reinforcement biases - but I think they can be compensated for by careful training/testing and perhaps by hybrid (ML + rule based) approaches. The reinforcement one seems to me trickier, as collecting training data is always hard and you have to be strong minded to abjure the lowest hanging fruit to hand! 
 
 Other things that concern me: 
 Commercial exploiters will be desperate to take "good enough" algorithms to market and the field may be held back by resistance to innovation, once they're making a lot of money. Users (as opposed to designers) may apply models trained for one scenario to inappropriate use-cases and discredit the technology when it fails and perhaps causes injury. More generally, machine intelligence failures will grab more headlines than successes, and this may hold back progress. Finally, I worry slightly that we're not planning enough (or maybe we are and I'm just not aware) - I'm not greatly worried about the "grey goo" dangers (though such fears are not outlandish) but more that we seem a bit obsessed with the idea of an autonomous thinking machine that can do everything itself - a contained intelligence, similar to individual humans - when (surely) the intelligence can more usefully reside in the web/network/internet/Culture, with relatively dumb machines doing the practical tasks we find difficult or dangerous (lifting heavy objects, defusing mines, etc).
